{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3441032,"name":"Ben Malito","username":"pinkfloyd145","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/pinkfloyd145/{size}/235516_2.png","created_at":"2024-10-29T01:19:08.549Z","cooked":"

For example, letâ€™s say the setting is Crescendo and I have a robot with a turret for a shooter. I want the robot to continuously angle the turret toward the speaker as soon as I enter the red allianceâ€™s side of the field (the taped off area), but while Iâ€™m not in the red allianceâ€™s side of the field it should be stationary.

I know this is possible, but my team has just figured out how to do things like localization and object detection, so I figured I would post here to see if anyone has any tips on how to do something like this. Or a nice place to get started perhaps? Thank you in advance!

You can use a trigger for this task.

For instance, you could do something like this that would run the turret aim command if the x coordinate of your pose estimation is less than 10 meters. You can extend this to check if the robot is on a specific part of the field.

new Trigger(() -> drive.getPose().getX() < 10).whileTrue(turretAimCommand);

This works, and Iâ€™d also like to throw out another possibility. Instead of a trigger, you can also check this in your periodic loop. It makes things work really nicely, especially if youâ€™re using state-based logic.

Using triggers is state-based. You just move the if condition somewhere else, and get cleaner and shorter code.

Thank you for the reply! As far as actually writing the command to aim the turret, would I be able to use a PID loop to keep the turret aimed at the target? That seems like the most common option to me but if you have a different suggestion Iâ€™m all ears

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2024-11-01T11:04:55.478Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":108,"readers_count":107,"score":26.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":473941,"topic_slug":"how-would-i-begin-to-make-a-robot-automatically-do-an-action-when-it-leaves-specified-coordinates-or-zones-on-the-field","display_username":"Ben Malito","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":54366,"username":"tecnicraze","name":"Noah Stricker","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tecnicraze/{size}/235517_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65606,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Control Systems"},"post_url":"/t/how-would-i-begin-to-make-a-robot-automatically-do-an-action-when-it-leaves-specified-coordinates-or-zones-on-the-field/473941/5","custom_user_title":"Control Systems","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3442470,"name":"Curt Rozeboom","username":"BlueEpiphone","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/blueepiphone/{size}/197122_2.png","created_at":"2024-11-01T11:50:50.949Z","cooked":"

Since you have said that you are just getting these things working for the first time, Iâ€™ll relay some advice on how to approach this from a good-enough perspective.

Yes, starting with just PID (usually P is enough or even just â€˜bang-bangâ€™ control depending on how fine grained you need to be) will get you to where the turret is at least moving towards its final target point, while the robot is still moving. Think of it as priming your aiming, but with the expectation that you wonâ€™t have your aim fine-tuned until youâ€™ve stopped moving, because being able to aim properly and shoot while moving is another level of difficulty altogether.

This can be accomplished before you even see the target by calculating the angle from the robot and target pose. (Edit - I looked up our code for this rather than relying on memory)

double x = currentTarget.get().getTranslation().getX() - robotPose.get().getTranslation().getX();|
double y = currentTarget.get().getTranslation().getY() - robotPose.get().getTranslation().getY();|
double angle = Math.atan2(y, x);|
return Units.radiansToDegrees(angle);|

The better you know your pose the better this works, though.

Once your target April Tag is visible to a targeting camera, you can switch to using PID on its yaw to center your turret. At this point, it would be a good idea to have some way of signaling the driver through LEDs or controller-rumble or a screen display that lets them know you are on target, so they donâ€™t shoot while still off-target.

Hope this helps!

If you donâ€™t have a separate targeting camera or pipeline, you may need to rely on getting an accurate pose update so the first algorithm can do the job. Or, you may just opt for using the targeting camera option only and wait for an April Tag to be in view.
